March 17, 2002: Fiction
THE SUMMONS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A law professor who
has been called home to Mississippi by his father, a dying judge, discovers more
than $3 million in cash in the old man's study.
THE COTTAGE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) An aging, virtually
penniless Hollywood star experiences excitement and even happiness after he
rents out part of his house.
UP COUNTRY, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A Vietnam veteran
investigates the mysterious death of an Army lieutenant three decades earlier.
THE DIARY OF ELLEN RIMBAUER, edited by Joyce Reardon. (Hyperion,
$22.95.) The fictional journal of the wife of a Seattle industrialist; a companion
volume to the mini-series "Stephen King's Rose Red."
SOUTHAMPTON ROW, by Anne Perry. (Ballantine, $25.) The Victorian police
detective Thomas Pitt tries to prevent a ruthless leader of a secret society from
acquiring an important seat in Parliament.
JOURNEY THROUGH HEARTSONGS, written and illustrated by Mattie J. T.
Stepanek. (VSP Books, $14.95.) A collection of poems by an 11-year-old boy who
suffers from muscular dystrophy.
HUNTING SEASON, by Nevada Barr. (Putnam, $24.95.) The park ranger Anna
Pigeon investigates the murder of a good ol' boy in Mississippi.
CATCH AS CAT CAN, by Rita Mae Brown and Sneaky Pie Brown. (Bantam,
$24.95.) With help from her cats, the postmaster of a small town in the Blue Ridge
Mountains looks into two mysterious deaths.
THE CORRECTIONS, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) A
multigenerational saga in which a mother tries to bring her dysfunctional family
together for a final Christmas at home.
THE MILLIONAIRES, by Brad Meltzer. (Warner, $25.95.) Things go awry when
two brothers who work at an exclusive bank try to pull off a foolproof crime.
SKIPPING CHRISTMAS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A husband and
wife discover that their decision to forgo Christmas comes with consequences.
BASKET CASE, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf, $25.95.) An obituary writer in South
Florida examines the strange circumstances surrounding the death of a rock star.
WARNING SIGNS, by Stephen White. (Delacorte, $24.95.) A clinical psychologist
in Colorado uncovers a link between one of his patients and the murder of the
Boulder County district attorney.
March 17, 2002
Non-Fiction
BIAS, by Bernard Goldberg. (Regnery, $27.95.) A television journalist who worked
at CBS for many years reports on "how the media distort the news."
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The man behind "Roger & Me" takes aim at Republicans and Democrats,
corporate America and our "nation of idiots."
SHADOW WARRIORS, by Tom Clancy with Carl Stiner and Tony Koltz. (Putnam,
$29.95.) An inside look at the United States' special-operations forces.
DRIVER #8, by Dale Earnhardt Jr. with Jade Gurss. (Warner, $23.95.) The race
car driver's account of his rookie year on the Nascar circuit.
THE BUREAU AND THE MOLE, by David A. Vise. (Atlantic Monthly, $25.) The
story of Robert Philip Hanssen, the counterintelligence expert for the F.B.I. who
was also a spy for Moscow.
SACRED CONTRACTS, by Caroline Myss. (Harmony, $25.) Reflections on
"spiritual energies" and the meaning of life by the author of "Anatomy of the Spirit."
ONE NATION, by the editors of Life magazine. (Little, Brown, $29.95.)
Photographs and essays dealing with the events of Sept. 11.
NIGGER, by Randall Kennedy. (Pantheon, $22.) A law professor explores "the
strange career of a troublesome word."
WHAT WENT WRONG? by Bernard Lewis. (Oxford University, $23.) A scholar of
Middle Eastern history examines the reaction of the Islamic world to being
overshadowed by the West.
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of
the country's first vice president and second president.
JACK: Straight From the Gut, by Jack Welch with John A. Byrne. (Warner
Business, $29.95.) The recently retired chairman and chief executive of General
Electric tells his story as well as G.E.'s.
THE DEATH OF THE WEST, by Patrick J. Buchanan. (Thomas Dunne/St.
Martin's, $25.95.) The right-wing pundit and former presidential candidate argues
that "immigrant invasions" threaten Western culture.
THE UNIVERSE IN A NUTSHELL, by Stephen Hawking. (Bantam, $35.) A
copiously illustrated book in which the physicist explains breakthroughs that have
occurred since he wrote "A Brief History of Time."
